question: Question_04_(c)
statement:
Determine whether the following improper integral is convergent or
divergent. Remember to justify your answer.

\[\int_1^\infty \frac{\sqrt{x}}{x^2 + x}dx\]
sols:
First notice that attempting to evaluate this integral is long and
tedious. Instead we attempt to find an integral which we know converges
or diverges, and compare our integral to that integral. Observe that on
the given interval, $[1,\infty)$ we have that $x^2+x > x^2$ and so
$\frac{\sqrt{x}}{x^2+x}<\frac{\sqrt{x}}{x^2}$. Hence,

\begin{align*}
\int_1^\infty \frac{\sqrt{x}}{x^2+x} dx &< \int_1^\infty \frac{\sqrt{x}}{x^2} dx \\
&=\int_1^\infty \frac{1}{x^{3/2}}dx \\
\end{align*}

and since we know that the integral $\int_1^\infty \frac{1}{x^p} dx$
converges whenever $p > 1$, we know that our integral does indeed
converge since $3/2 > 1$.
hints:
Find a standard integral which you know converges or diverges and
compare this integral to that standard integral.
